column4: anyone know how to view the local network and maybe connect to local machines through the terminal? and will it be a problem if i try connecting to a local machine running windows xp
anyone know how to view the local network and maybe connect to local machines through the terminal? and will it be a problem if i try connecting to a local machine running windows xp
cshadowrun: is this already in main repo? and its terminal based correct?
cshadowrun: its cool, thanks for the help though
ecclesiastes: do you know what command i would use to do that?
ecclesiastes: connect through the local network to another machine
ecclesiastes: which program would u recommend for that?
ecclesiastes: and how do i get local machine IPs?
ecclesiastes: im just curious, and want to do it in terminal
use smbtree to list available shares
you use ssh IP
to find IPs on network you can do 'nmap 192.168.1.0/24 -sP' (assuming you are using IPs in range 192.168.1.x)
or just ifconfig on target machine
ssh is a linux program, it is possible to install on windows, but not the same at all,,, you probably want rdesktop to control a windows desktop
why use rdesktop? cause its more suitable for windows environment?
because ssh is not in windows
oh rdesktop = remote desktop ... LOL im slow atm running on very little sleep :S... but remote desktop has to be enabled on the other machine correct?
Ecclesiastes the answer is easy, in windows, go to control panel>system>remote and enable remote desktop, then in linux, connect to that IP using rdesktop, done
im doing this just for fun, so ill prolly do both (or atleast try to use both ways)
there is no other way, telnet is not the way to go
Ecclesiastes look at http://linux.die.net/man/1/rdesktop
